Table 1 Succinic acid Methyl acrylate complex ΔG complex ΔG TDI a 53 0.0 516 -13.7 TDTS b 5TS4-5 22.0 3TS2-3 35.6 TOF 1.67 0.042 a Rate-determining intermediate (TDI).[75] b Rate-determining transition state (TDTS).[75] Mechanistic insight into the carboxylic derivatives formation from CO2 and ethylene over iron(0)-based catalyst Xinxin Ding Software Investigation Writing – original draft Yue Mu Methodology Youcai Zhu Methodology Xing Guo Software Writing – review & editing Kaimin Liu Software Writing – review & editing Li Sun Validation Zhen Liu Project administration Writing – review & editing ⁎ School of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai 200237, China School of Chemical Engineering East China University of Science and Technology Shanghai 200237 China School of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai 200237, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Since the 1980s, nickel/palladium-based catalysts have been extensively studied for the coupling reactions of CO2 and ethylene. In this study, the CO2 and ethylene coupling mediated by the iron(0)-based catalyst with a bis(dicyclohexylphosphino)ethane (dcpe) ligand was systematically investigated by means of DFT calculations. The DFT functionals were first subjected to a benchmark test in order to describe an iron-catalyzed reaction with a two-state reactivity (TSR). For the Fe/dcpe catalytic system, the formation of the five-membered iron-lactone 3 follows a stepwise route, which is easy to occur with a low energy barrier of 13.8 kcal/mol. The competing reactions by CO2 insertion and β-H elimination determine the fate of the five-membered iron-lactone 3, which may lead to the formation of three different products, including the formation of i) succinic acid, ii) iso-methylmalonic acid, and iii) acrylic acid. The calculated TOFs showed that CO2 insertion into the five-membered iron-lactone 3 is more likely to occur (1.67 h−1 for the formation of succinic acid) compared with the β-H elimination leading to iso-methylmalonic acid and acrylic acid. Interestingly, β-H elimination can be effectively facilitated by addition of the electrophiles, and a comparable TOF of 0.042 h−1 was obtained for the formation of methyl acrylate in the presence of CH3I. Unlike nickel-/palladium-catalyzed CO2 and ethylene coupling reactions, all four iron(0)-catalyzed reaction routes investigated herein showed a two-state reactivity scenario involving spin crossover between triplet and quintet PESs. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the intriguing iron(0)-catalyzed CO2 and ethylene coupling reactions, which may shed some light on the development of green catalysts for CO2 utilization. Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Iron catalyst CO2 insertion β-H elimination Methylation Two-state reactivity Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide is a cheap, non-toxic, and naturally abundant C1 building block.[1,2] The use of CO2 as a feedstock for the synthesis of important commodity chemicals provides a more cost-effective and renewable alternative to conventional fossil fuel carbon sources.[3,4] However, the efficient conversion of CO2 is greatly hampered by its thermodynamic stability and kinetic inertness (ΔG°f = -94.7 kcal/mol).[5–7] In the past decades, some reactions mediated by transition metal complexes have been reported in converting CO2 into certain chemical products by organocatalyzed trapping of CO2 through C-C bond forming reactions, including the production of cyclic organic carbonates, polycarbonates, and carboxylic acids etc.[8–13] For instance, the coupling of CO2 and ethylene is of high atomic efficiency, and the coupling products including the succinic acid and acrylic acid are important chemical intermediates in wide industrial applications, such as coatings, plastics, rubber, adhesives, pharmaceuticals, etc.[1,14] The first fixation of CO2 into organic compounds was reported by Inoue et al. using Pd-phosphine catalysts.[15,16] Later, Hoberg et al. and Carmona et al. respectively reported the CO2 and ethylene coupling reactions using Ni-, Mo-, and W-based transition metal complexes.[17–19] It is widely accepted that the reaction starts from the ethylene complex, since it is found to be more stable according to DFT calculations and its formation prior to lactone formation is observed experimentally.[20–25] Pápai et al. confirmed that the formation of the nickel-ethylene complex (byp)Ni(C2H4) is energetically more feasible than the formation of the nickel-CO2 complex (byp)Ni(CO2) by 6.7 kcal/mol.[23] The C-C coupling step is believed to start from the well-characterized ethylene-coordinated metal complexes, whereas the metal-CO2 complexes displayed very limited reactivity.[26,27] The attack of CO2 on the coordinated olefin is a common feature of many transition metal complexes bearing olefin ligands.[28] However, the acrylic acid is hard to be released from the highly stable five-membered metallalactone, which is resistant to β-hydrogen elimination and the cleavage of the strong metal-O bond. Until 2006, Walther et al. utilized a Ni-based catalyst bearing a ‘right’ bis(diphenylphosphino)methane (dppm) ligand for the CO2 and ethylene coupling reaction.[29] The NMR spectroscopy and X-ray analysis demonstrated the formation of a dimeric Ni(I) complex containing a bridging acrylate ligand, which is formed by β-H elimination of the nickelalactone. In addition, β-H elimination could also be realized by introducing external promotors to cleavage the metallacycles, such as alkylation reagents (CH3I),[30–32] alkali-metal bases (NaOtBu),[33] Lewis acids,[34] etc. Unlike nickelalactone and palladalactone, which usually undergo ring cleavage in the presence of external promoters, the iron-lactone tends to undergo further insertion of ethylene or CO2 to yield saturated/unsaturated carboxylic acids and diacids.[35,36] Hoberg et al. reported that CO2 could be further inserted into iron-lactone to proceed with ring expansion reaction. By addition of 1,2-bis(dicyclohexylphosphino)ethane (dcpe) ligand, the molar ratio of succinic acid and iso-methylmalonic acid was detected to be 10:1 for the coupling reaction of CO2 and ethylene.[35] However, Chirik et al. successfully prepared macrocyclic metallalactones from multiple insertion of C2H4 into the five-membered iron-lactone intermediate using pyridine(diimine) iron dinitrogen complex, and the size of the iron-lactone could be controlled by tuning the ratio of CO2 and ethylene.[36] Bernskoetter et al. characterized the intermediate iron-lactone complex (depe)2Fe(κC,κO-CH2CH2COO) (depe = 1,2-bis(diethylphosphino)ethane) through NMR spectroscopy and X-ray diffraction experiments.[37] However, no detailed studies have been conducted so far to elucidate the catalytic behavior of iron-catalyzed coupling reaction of CO2 and ethylene, which is usually accompanied by the formation of iron carbonate complexes, readily decarbonylation, and the crossover of two spin-state energy surfaces.[38,39] In this study, special attention has been paid to the crossover of the multiple spin-state energy surfaces of iron(0)-based complexes, including the singlet, triplet, and quintet surfaces. Then, the formation of succinic acid, iso-methylmalonic acid, and acrylic acid from coupling of CO2 and ethylene mediated by iron catalyst bearing a bisphosphine ligand dcpe were systematically investigated. In addition, methylation reactions were investigated in the presence of CH3I to explore the potential of iron-lactone to produce methyl acrylate from CO2-ethylene coupling. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first detailed theoretical study on the iron-catalyzed coupling reaction of CO2 and ethylene, which may shed some light on the development of novel catalyst systems for the utilization of carbon dioxide. 2 Computational details 2.1 Computational method All DFT calculations were carried out by using the Gaussian 09 program package.[40] The geometries of all intermediates were fully optimized without any symmetry constraint by using the hybrid B3LYP functional, in combination with the double-zeta basis set 6-31G(d,p) for C, H, O, P, and Fe atoms, and LANL2DZ for I atom.[41–45] Truhlar's SMD solvation model [46] with tetrahydrofuran as the model solvent and Grimme's dispersion (keyword: emp=gd3) were incorporated into the geometry optimizations.[47] Vibrational frequency calculations were carried out to verify the nature of the optimized structures and to obtain the thermal correction to the Gibbs free energies. All minima were confirmed to have no imaginary frequency and all transition states displayed only one appropriate imaginary frequency that exhibits a vibrational mode consistent with the path in the reaction scenario. The transition states and intermediates were validated by intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) calculations.[48] The electronic energies of all structures have been refined by carrying out single-point energy calculations using a large triple-zeta basis set def2-TZVP for all atoms. The DFT functionals employed for electronic energy refinement were benchmarked against the DLPNO-CCSD(T) energies, which were calculated using the ORCA 5.0 program with a triple-zeta basis set def2-TZVPP.[49] The ground spin state for each stationary point was explored on all plausible spin-state energy surfaces. The minimum energy crossing points (MECPs) were located using the code developed by Harvey.[50,51] The three-dimensional (3D) geometries were rendered by CYLview.[52] The spin density analysis of the related species was performed using Multiwfn 3.6 program.[53] The steric map and buried volume calculations were performed with the SambVca. 2.1 developed by Cavallo et al.[54] 2.2 Catalytic cycle For iron(0)-catalyzed coupling of CO2 and ethylene, the reaction starts with a stepwise mechanism (Scheme 1 ): i) the coordination of CO2 to the ethylene-coordinated iron-complex 1; and ii) the coupling of CO2 and ethylene resulting in the formation of the key intermediate iron-lactone 3, which is different from the formation of the nickelalactone and palladalactone previously reported in a concerted manner by coupling of CO2 and ethylene.[6,20,55] Then, two routes may follow: further insertion of CO2 vs. β-H elimination. The metallactone 3 proceeds CO2 insertion after coordination of a second CO2 molecule, giving an enlarged iron carboxylate 5. After hydrolysis from 5 by HCl, succinic acid 6 is released (path I). Alternatively, the competitive β-H elimination of the iron-lactone 3 generates a hydrido-acrylate complex 7. Subsequently, the η 3-O,C,C-coordinated complex 7′ is formed by rotation of the iron-hydrogen bond in the highly unstable hydrido-acrylate complex 7. Next, the hydrogen transfer from the metal center to the α-C atom in the vinyl group of carboxylic acid moiety gives a four-membered metallactone 8. The iso-methylmalonic acid 11 is liberated from complex 10 by addition of HCl (path II). Additionally, the hydrido-acrylate complex 7 can undergo intramolecular rearrangement to give k 1-O-coordinated complex 12, followed by the formation of the k 1-O-coordinated acrylic acid complex 13 through hydrogen transfer from the metal center to the oxygen. Ligand exchange of acrylic acid by ethylene leads to the detachment of the acrylic acid and the regeneration of the ethylene-coordinated iron complex 1 (path III). 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Benchmarking test The spin surface crossing can affect the catalytic performance of the transition metal complexes, which has been consistently observed for iron-catalyzed reactions.[56–59] DFT functionals with different amount of Hartree–Fock exchange would have a significant effect on the relative energies between two different spin states.[60] Therefore, 13 functionals including six hybrid functionals and seven pure functionals were first benchmarked by taking the high-level DLPNO-CCSD(T) energy as a reference. Specifically, the benchmark was carried out on two key structures including the key intermediate 3 and the transition state TS3-7. The energy gap between triplet 33 and quintet 53 and the reaction energy of 3TS3-7 relative to 53 are illustrated in Fig. 1 . The energy gaps between singlet 13 and quintet 53, and singlet 13 and triplet 33 are listed in Table S1 in the Supplementary Materials. Clearly, the iron-lactone complex favors a quintet ground spin state with an energy gap of 16.0 kcal/mol calculated at the DLPNO-CCSD(T) level of theory. However, the transition state TS3-7 favors a triplet ground spin state, which was calculated to be 32.5 kcal/mol above the reference 53 (Fig. 1 and Table S1). For the hybrid DFT functionals, the Minnesota hybrid meta GGA functional M06 almost reproduced the DLPNO-CCSD(T) energies, with a calculated 14.7 kcal/mol for the triplet and quintet energy gap for 3, and a calculated 31.4 kcal/mol for the energy of 3TS3-7 relative to 53. The classical hybrid functional B3LYP gives a reasonably good calculation on the relative energy of 3TS3-7, but with a large discrepancy in the prediction of the energy gap between triplet 33 and quintet 53. All the pure functionals failed in the benchmark. By considering the benchmark results, the hybrid functional M06 was selected for all the following mechanistic investigations. We further calculated the singlet, triplet, and quintet energies for key intermediates involved in the catalytic cycle (Scheme 1). The singlet energy surface can be safely excluded due to the high-energy nature of all structures relative to the energy on the triplet and quintet surfaces. The reaction is calculated with a two-state reactivity, which proceeds on the quintet and triplet potential energy surfaces (PESs),[57,61] as depicted in Fig. S1 in the Supplementary Materials. 3.2 Formation of iron-lactone The Gibbs free energy profiles for the formation of the five-membered iron-lactone 3 are shown in Fig. 2 . The calculations reveal that the formation of the ethylene-coordinated complex 1 is favored energetically than the CO2-coordinated complex for Fe/dcpe catalytic system (Table S2 in the Supplementary Materials). This result is in accordance with the prior examples of CO2 and ethylene oxidative coupling that ethylene already coordinates with the metal center in the starting structure.[20,23,37] The ethylene-coordinated iron complex 1 has a triplet ground spin state and lies below the quintet state by 8.0 kcal/mol. Subsequently, the coordination of CO2 to the iron center results in the formation of the complex (dcpe)Fe(C2H4)(CO2) 2, which only lies 0.8 kcal/mol higher in energy than 1 on the triplet surface. It is therefore more likely that complex 2 is a stable intermediate. The binding mode of CO2 with the Fe center transforms from the η 2(C, O) coordination mode in 32 to the η 1(C) coordination mode in 52, while the C2H4 molecule is stably coordinated to the Fe center through d-π interaction (Fig. S2 in the Supplementary Materials).[62,63] The formation of the iron-lactone 3 (dcpe)Fe(kC,kO-CH2CH2COO) by C-C coupling in a two-step manner needs to overcome an energy barrier of 13.8 kcal/mol on the triplet surface. The generated iron-lactone complex 3 has a quintet ground spin state through the spin flip via CP1 , which is located at 6.2 kcal/mol above 33. The formation of the iron-lactone 3 is an exergonic process because the metallalactone species lie below the ethylene-coordinated complex 1 by 21.8 kcal/mol on the free energy profiles. Hence, C-C coupling is a facile reaction pathway in the presence of the Fe/dcpe catalyst with a relatively low energy barrier, which starts from a triplet (dcpe)Fe(C2H4) complex and results in the formation of quintet iron-lactone 3. The iron-lactone 33 displays near planarity with a Fe(1)-O(2)-C(3)-P(5) moderate distortion of 3.9°, which shows a geometric feature similar to the planar Ni- and Mo-lactones (Fig. 3 a).[23,26] The relatively stable 53 shows a folding chair conformation with the Fe(1)-O(2) bond distance of 1.955 Å, which is slightly elongated than that in 33 (1.920 Å). The iron-lactone 33 and 53 involve the nearly planar five-membered metallacycle as illustrated by two small dihedral angles of 4.2° and 7.3°, respectively. Additionally, a spin density analysis was performed to determine the electron distribution of the iron-lactone 33 and 53 (Fig. 3b). An electron with ms = +1/2 is denoted as α-spin electron (spin up), while an electron with ms = -1/2 is denoted as β-spin electron (spin down).[64] The positive spin density within the blue region indicates more α-spin electrons than β-spin electrons. The α-spin electrons are dominantly located on the Fe center, with some distribution spotted on the C and O atoms in the vicinity of the Fe center for 53. The distribution of β-electrons is mainly concentrated on the C and O atoms adjacent to the Fe center for 33. The total spin population number (electron numbers of (α−β)) is approximately equal to the number of unpaired electrons. The spin population number on 53 is 3.906 as shown in Fig. 3b, suggesting that there are about four unpaired α electrons in 53. 3.3 Expansion and decomposition of iron-lactone Starting from the five-membered iron-lactone 3, the competitive CO2 insertion and β-H elimination determine the fate of the five-membered iron-lactone. The ring expansion by the insertion of a second CO2 into iron-lactone 3 furnishes succinic acid (path I, scheme 1), while the β-H elimination leading to the decomposition of iron-lactone yields the iso-methylmalonic acid (path II, scheme 1) or acrylic acid (path III, scheme 1). 3.3.1 Formation of succinic acid The CO2 insertion into the iron-lactone 53 leads to the formation of 55 via transition state 5TS4-5 with a relatively low energy barrier of 22.0 kcal/mol (Fig. 4 ). Both 4 and 5 have a quintet ground state, and 3TS4-5 lies above 5TS4-5 by 18.7 kcal/mol, which indicates that this reaction proceeds on a single quintet PES without spin crossover. The calculated relative free energy for iron carboxylate 55 is exoergic (ΔG = -14.1 kcal/mol), which demonstrates that CO2 insertion into the iron-lactone is thermodynamically favorable. Finally, succinic acid can be obtained after acid hydrolysis followed by regeneration of the starting complex 1. Our DFT studies shown in Fig. 4 indicated that CO2 insertion into the iron-lactone 53 leads to 55 formation is a favorable pathway due to the highly exoergic CO2 insertion reaction (ΔG = −14.1 kcal/mol) coupled with an appropriate barrier (ΔG ⧧ =22.0 kcal/mol) in Fe/dcpe catalytic system. 3.3.2 Formation of iso-methylmalonic acid For the competitive reaction, the energy barrier of β-H elimination of the iron-lactone 53 generating the intermediate 7 with an iron-hydrogen bond amounts to 29.1 kcal/mol on the triplet surface, which is much lower than that of 38.7 kcal/mol on the quintet surface. Apparently, β-H elimination of iron-lactone involves two spin crossovers between triplet and quintet PESs, and the energy barrier for β-H elimination is lowered by 9.6 kcal/mol via CP1 and CP2 , which accelerates the β-H elimination reaction.[65] As depicted in Fig. S3 in the Supplementary Materials, the distances of Fe(1)-C(3) bond and Fe(1)-O(2) bond in CP1 are 2.032 Å, 1.903 Å, respectively, indicating a geometrical similarity of CP1 to those of 33 (Fig. 3a). Starting from highly unstable hydrido-acrylate 7, two possible pathways may follow: i) the formation of dicarboxylate 10; or ii) the formation of k 1-O-coordinated acrylic acid complex 13. A rotation of metal-hydrogen moiety of hydrido-acrylate 7 to η 3-O,C,C-coordinated 7′ is downhill in free energy (∼15.0 kcal/mol), while a further intramolecular rearrangement of 7 to the k 1-O-coordinated hydrido complex 12 lowers the free energy by ∼10.9 kcal/mol. The transition state 3TS7′-8 for the hydrogen transferring from the iron center to α-C atom to generate the four-membered lactone 8 is located at 25.3 kcal/mol above the 53 (Fig. 5 ). CP3′and CP3′′ lie 19.7 and 6.2 kcal/mol above quintets 57′ and 58, respectively. The geometrical features of triplet and quintet 7′ (Fig. S4) show that much longer distances of Fe(1)-C(3) and H(2)-C(3) bonds in 57′ than those in 37′, which indicates less interaction between the vinyl group and the high-spin iron center.[57] Subsequently, a CO2 molecule attacks on the Fe-C bond in the complex 58, generating a new C-C bond via the transition state 5TS9-10. The formation of 510 is exoergic by 20.1 kcal/mol with respect to 58. The transition state 5TS9-10 with less steric hindrance (%VBur = 89.5%) displays shorter distance of 2.109 Å for Fe-C(CO2) and 2.256 Å for Fe-O(CO2) compared with the transition state 5TS4-5 (Fig. 6 ). The NPA charges of CO2 moieties in the transition states 5TS9-10 and 5TS4-5 are -0.480 and -0.503, respectively, indicating that electrons transfer to CO2 facilitates the CO2 insertion reaction. Both the reaction with β-H elimination of iron-lactone 3 and the formation of larger metallacycle 10 through CO2 insertion are calculated to be less favored compared with the reaction pathway for the formation of metallacycle 5. 3.3.3 Formation of acrylic acid As shown in Fig. 7 , the formation of k 1-O-coordinated acrylic acid complex 513 through hydrogen transferring to the carboxyl oxygen is prohibited by presenting a surprisingly high energy transition state 3TS12-13 above 53, at 68.2 kcal/mol, which lies 2.3 kcal/mol below 5TS12-13. The crossing point CP4′ is located at 18.2 kcal/mol above 512 and 4.0 kcal/mol above 312 (Fig. 7). Consequently, the acrylic acid complex 13 is formed via CP4′′ in Fe/dcpe catalytic system, which is highly disfavored kinetically and thermodynamically. Although the ligand exchange [24] is promising for Fe-assisted system (Table S3 in the Supplementary Materials), however, the endergonic nature of the overall reaction (35.2 kcal/mol above 53 via CP5 ) and the high activation barrier for the hydrogen transfer to the oxygen (68.2 kcal/mol relative to 53) lead to an extremely difficult path for the coupling of CO2 and ethylene to give acrylic acid. These results may explain why iron-based catalysts are barely employed to produce acrylic acid but to produce dicarboxylic acids. Generally, the lack of reactivity for acrylic acid formation in Fe/dcpe catalytic system can be attributed to the barrier for β-H elimination and the absence of a lower-energy pathway for the hydrogen transfer to the carboxyl oxygen. 3.4 Formation of methyl acrylate assisted by CH3I The reaction for acrylic acid is calculated to be endergonic and needs to overcome a high energy barrier of 68.2 kcal/mol for the hydrogen transfer from the iron center to oxygen, which suggests that the direct coupling reaction of CO2 and ethylene to prepare acrylic acid by Fe/dcpe catalyst is unlikely to occur. These limitations can be overcome by addition of certain electrophiles such as CH3I.[30,66,67] Herein, we calculated the methyl acrylate formation assisted by CH3I in Fe/dcpe system (Fig. 8 , path IV), with considering the triplet and quintet reaction pathways (Table S4 in the Supplementary Materials). Kühn et al. [68] proposed a concerted methylation route to fully break the Ni-O bond by attaching the -CH3 group to the oxygen atom connected with the nickel center, which requires to overcome an unreasonably high barrier of 58.6 kcal/mol. Contrasting the concerted methylation mechanism, Limbach et al.[66] elucidated a two-step mechanism (SN2 mechanism) to cleave the M-O bond by methylation, implying electrophilic attack of -CH3 group on the oxygen O1 connected with the metal center or the carbonyl O2, followed by the iodide transfer to the metal center leading to a ring-opened intermediate. We considered these three routes for the methylation of iron-lactone 3 assisted by CH3I in Fe/dcpe system, as shown in Fig. 8. The methylation occurs most likely via O2 attack route with an activation barrier of 22.3 kcal/mol on the quintet spin state, which is lower than these of O1 attack route (23.6 kcal/mol) and concerted route (34.3 kcal/mol). Notably, all the above-mentioned methylation reactions proceed on the quintet PES without spin crossover. The iodide moves toward the metal center in intermediates 14 and 15 after associated transition states 5TS3-14 and 5TS3-15 (Fig. 8), leading to a significant weakening of the Fe-O bond. Subsequently, the iodide moves into the equatorial plane with the decoordination of the oxygen atom with the metal center, indicating a complete cleavage of the Fe−O bond to give a more stable intermediate 16. The ring-opened intermediate 16 needs to undergo β-H elimination to produce methyl acrylate. The 516 is determined to be the ground state and lies 20.2 kcal/mol below 316 (Table S4 in the Supplementary Materials). The triplet 3TS16-17 is lower than that of the quintet 5TS16-17 by 8.7 kcal/mol. The crossing point CP6 (7.3 kcal/mol) connects the quintet and triplet PESs, which lies 21.0 kcal/mol above 516 and 0.8 kcal/mol above 316. The overall energy barrier for β-H elimination is therefore 24.0 kcal/mol involving two spin surface crossings via CP6 and CP7 (Fig. S5 in the Supplementary Materials). Subsequently, methyl acrylate can be released from complex 17, forming the (dcpe)FeHI complex 18. Ligand exchange between C2H4 and HI moiety of complex 18 affords the regeneration of complex 1. The reaction energy is -21.6 kcal/mol, demonstrating that the methyl acrylate formation is thermodynamically feasible for Fe/dcpe system (Table S5 in the Supplementary Materials). Therefore, Fe/dcpe system can be considered as a potential catalyst to produce methyl acrylate through methylation reaction assisted by CH3I, which features a two-state reactivity (TSR) involving quintet state and triplet states (Table S4 in the Supplementary Materials). Electrostatic potential (ESP) on the van der Waals (vdW) surface plays a role in predicting preferential reaction sites.[69–73] In order to reveal the priority of the reaction sites between oxygen O1 or carbonyl O2 and -CH3 group of CH3I reasonably, the ESP surface is mapped to the molecular vdW surface of 53 and CH3I, as displayed in Fig. 9 . The surface sites with more negative ESP values have a stronger tendency to attract electrophiles, in which it probably become the potential reaction site. Similarly, the surface sites possessing more positive ESP values are the most likely interaction sites with the nucleophiles. The ESP surface of CH3I displays a positive region located at the region of the -CH3 group. Meanwhile, the local minima (or global minima) on the surface of 53 are located on carbonyl O2 on the metallacycles, the PES surfaces of oxygen O1 connected with the metal center show no extreme points. The average ESP of oxygen O1 of 53 is -40.25 kcal/mol, which is 15.15 kcal/mol higher than that of the carbonyl O2. Consequently, from the perspective of ESP distribution, the oxygen O2 with more negative ESP values is the electrophilic site attacked by CH3I, which explains the favored O2 attack route for the cleavage of the iron-lactone 3. 3.5 Comparison of the fate of iron-lactone It is straightforward to compare the activity and selectivity of the competitive reactions by means of turnover frequencies (TOFs).[74] The relative Gibbs free energy and TOFs to yield succinic acid, iso-methylmalonic acid, acrylic acid, and methyl acrylate are summarized in Table S5 in the Supplementary Materials. The calculated TOFs based on energetic span model [75] indicate that iron-based catalyst shows a notable activity for succinic acid formation (1.67 h−1, Table 1 ). It is obvious that CO2 insertion into the five-membered iron-lactone leading to succinic acid is more likely to occur compared with the β-H elimination leading to iso-methylmalonic acid and acrylic acid in iron-catalyzed CO2 and ethylene coupling, which is in agreement with the experimental observations.[35] The limitations of the endergonic reaction and the high activation barrier for the proposed hydrogen transfer from the iron-lactone can be overcome by addition of an electrophile CH3I. The calculated TOF for the CH3I assisted acrylate formation is 0.042 h−1 (Table 1), which is significantly large than that of acrylic acid formation catalyzed by the iron-based systems. Therefore, acrylate formation by coupling of CO2 and ethylene is another promising way for the catalytic transformation of CO2 by utilizing certain methylation agents in the presence of iron catalysts. 4 Conclusions In this work, we systematically investigated the mechanism of CO2 and ethylene coupling for the formation of carboxylic derivatives over iron-based catalyst. It is of crucial importance to choose an appropriate DFT level to describe the iron catalyzed reactions, which usually proceed with a two-state reactivity. The hybrid functional M06 was recognized to be able to reproduce the energy gaps between two adjacent potential energy surfaces (triplet and quintet) and the key activation barriers by taking the DLPNO-CCSD(T) energies as a reference. The coupling reactions of CO2 and ethylene starts with the formation of a mono-ethylene coordinated iron complex on the triplet surface. The first spin surface crossing takes place after the transition state TS2-3, which results in the formation of the key intermediate 3. C-C coupling is a facile reaction pathway in the presence of the Fe/dcpe catalyst with an energy barrier of 13.8 kcal/mol and a favourable exergonic process of 21.8 kcal/mol. The consecutive insertion of CO2 into the five-membered iron-lactone is superior in competing with the intramolecular β-H transfer (29.1 kcal/mol), evidently by presenting a moderate energy barrier of 22.0 kcal/mol for the formation of succinic acid. The lack of reactivity toward acrylic acid formation in Fe/dcpe catalytic system can be attributed to the high barrier for β-H elimination and the absence of a lower-energy pathway for the hydrogen transfer to the carboxyl oxygen (68.2 kcal/mol). Interestingly, the β-H elimination of the five-membered iron-lactone can be effectively promoted by addition of some electrophiles. The methylation most likely occurs via O2 pathway with a low barrier of 22.3 kcal/mol, which can be ascribed to the more negative electrostatic potential of the carbonyl oxygen O2. The calculated TOFs show that the formation of methyl acrylate in the presence of CH3I (0.042 h−1) is already comparable to the formation of succinic acid (1.67 h−1). Unlike nickel-/palladium-catalyzed CO2 and ethylene coupling reactions, all four iron(0)-catalyzed reaction routes showed a two-state reactivity scenario involving spin crossover between triplet and quintet PESs. The present work provided some novel insights into the intriguing iron(0)-catalyzed CO2 and ethylene coupling reactions. Our ongoing work is focused on improving the catalytic performance of the iron(0)-based catalysts, which may guide the design of the green and affordable catalysts for industrial utilization of CO2. coredata.dc:description: Since the 1980s, nickel/palladium-based catalysts have been extensively studied for the coupling reactions of CO2 and ethylene. In this study, the CO2 and ethylene coupling mediated by the iron(0)-based catalyst with a bis(dicyclohexylphosphino)ethane (dcpe) ligand was systematically investigated by means of DFT calculations. The DFT functionals were first subjected to a benchmark test in order to describe an iron-catalyzed reaction with a two-state reactivity (TSR). For the Fe/dcpe catalytic system, the formation of the five-membered iron-lactone 3 follows a stepwise route, which is easy to occur with a low energy barrier of 13.8 kcal/mol. The competing reactions by CO2 insertion and β-H elimination determine the fate of the five-membered iron-lactone 3, which may lead to the formation of three different products, including the formation of i) succinic acid, ii) iso-methylmalonic acid, and iii) acrylic acid. The calculated TOFs showed that CO2 insertion into the five-membered iron-lactone 3 is more likely to occur (1.67 h−1 for the formation of succinic acid) compared with the β-H elimination leading to iso-methylmalonic acid and acrylic acid. Interestingly, β-H elimination can be effectively facilitated by addition of the electrophiles, and a comparable TOF of 0.042 h−1 was obtained for the formation of methyl acrylate in the presence of CH3I. Unlike nickel-/palladium-catalyzed CO2 and ethylene coupling reactions, all four iron(0)-catalyzed reaction routes investigated herein showed a two-state reactivity scenario involving spin crossover between triplet and quintet PESs. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the intriguing iron(0)-catalyzed CO2 and ethylene coupling reactions, which may shed some light on the development of green catalysts for CO2 utilization.
coredata.dc:title: Mechanistic insight into the carboxylic derivatives formation from CO2 and ethylene over iron(0)-based catalyst
